data.title: Giuseppe Garibaldi
data.text:
Giuseppe Garibaldi, accompanied by his red-shirted army, began his rapidly spreading rebellion in May of 1860; this rebellion played a crucial role in the unification of Italy. By 1861 the Kingdom of Italy was proclaimed, and Garibaldi’s rebellion was declared a success. This was an unauthorized rebellion by the government, but they didn’t stop him. Victor Emmanuel II, ruler of the kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia and Camillo di Cavour, the prime minister were in support of the unification of Italy, but after their losses to Austria, feared the loss of rule under the popularity of Garibaldi. Victor Emmanuel II and Garibaldi’s forces met in Naples, and to the surprise of the people, Garibaldi threw his support to the King and united, unifying Italy. The Report on the Conquest of Naples, written in 1860 by Giuseppe Garibaldi is a personal recap of the events leading up to the unification of Italy, primarily explaining the opportunities that led to the conquest of Naples, Italy. He begins by looking back at the task of crossing the strait, which was the Strait of Messina. This was the connection between Sicily and Naples, the largest city in Italy. He conquered Sicily and declared himself dictator in the name of Victor Emmanuel II. He was proud of the conquering of Sicily but still had…

Giuseppe Garibaldi, born Joseph Marie Garibaldi, was born on July 4th, 1807 in Nice, France, and died in Caprera, Italy on July 2nd, 1882 at the age of 79. Garibaldi, with the assistance of Camillo di Cavour, was able to help Italy become a united nation. Camillo was the brains of the operation, but Garibaldi used his brawn, and became the known as the militia force of the duo. They finally succeeded in unifying Italy in the year of 1840. Giuseppe Mazzini was an Italian nationalist, patriot, and revolutionary leader during the 19th century. Before Italian unification was achieved, Italy had been divided into several states, which were dominated by Austrian authority. Mazzini was quite radical for his time, as he believed that Italy should be unified as a democratic republic where there was universal suffrage, which enfranchised women.
